cards.front: What distinguishes a transfer characteristic from a driving-point characteristic?
cards.back: A driving-point characteristic has input and response at the same port. A transfer characteristic has input at one port and output at a different port. The word 'transfer' means the response is observed at a port different from where the excitation is applied.

cards.front: For two series resistors with input vi and output vo = v2, what are the KCL and KVL constraints?
cards.back: KCL: i = i1 = i2 (same current through both). KVL: vi = v1 + v2 = v-hat1(i) + v-hat2(i). Output: vo = v-hat2(i).

cards.front: How do you obtain the transfer characteristic vo(vi) from parametric equations?
cards.back: Express vi = f(i) and vo = h(i). Then eliminate i: vo = h(f^{-1}(vi)). If analytic inversion is not feasible, compute (vi, vo) pairs for many values of i and plot.

cards.front: Why is the parametric method useful for deriving transfer characteristics?
cards.back: It avoids the need to invert f(i) analytically, which is often impossible for nonlinear elements. You simply tabulate vi and vo for many values of the parameter i and plot the resulting curve.

cards.front: For a diode (R1) in series with a linear resistor (R2), what is vo when vi is well above V_gamma?
cards.back: vo is approximately vi - V_gamma. The diode voltage is pinned near V_gamma, so nearly all additional input voltage appears across R2.

cards.front: For a diode-resistor series circuit, what is vo when vi < V_gamma?
cards.back: vo is approximately 0. Below the turn-on voltage, the diode conducts negligible current, so the voltage across R2 is essentially zero.

cards.front: What is the transfer characteristic of a purely linear voltage divider (R1 and R2)?
cards.back: vo = R2/(R1 + R2) * vi. A straight line through the origin with slope less than 1.

cards.front: What does the slope of the transfer characteristic represent?
cards.back: The incremental voltage gain: dvo/dvi. A slope greater than 1 means amplification; less than 1 means attenuation; varying slope means the circuit is nonlinear.

cards.front: What three pieces of information does a transfer characteristic encode?
cards.back: Gain (slope dvo/dvi), offset (constant voltage shift between input and output), and linearity (how the slope varies with input level).

cards.front: Why can a nonlinear transfer characteristic perform functions that a linear one cannot?
cards.back: A varying slope means the circuit treats small and large signals differently. This enables rectification, limiting, amplitude compression, and other nonlinear signal-processing functions that require signal-level-dependent behaviour.
